questions.question: What is this logic gate called?
questions.svg: <svg width="200" height="120" viewBox="0 0 200 120"><line x1="20" y1="40" x2="55" y2="40" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="20" y1="80" x2="55" y2="80" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 55 25 Q 65 25 65 60 Q 65 95 55 95 L 55 25" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 65 25 Q 120 45 120 60 Q 120 75 65 95" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="80" y1="50" x2="80" y2="70" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="120" y1="60" x2="180" y2="60" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><text x="20" y="35" font-size="12" fill="#374151">A</text><text x="20" y="95" font-size="12" fill="#374151">B</text><text x="165" y="55" font-size="12" fill="#374151">Q</text></svg>
questions.hint: Notice the extra curved line at the input. This 'exclusive' gate outputs 1 only when inputs are different.

questions.question: What is $1 \oplus 1$ (1 XOR 1)?
questions.hint: XOR returns $1$ when inputs are DIFFERENT. What happens when both inputs are the same?

questions.question: What is this logic gate called?
questions.svg: <svg width="200" height="120" viewBox="0 0 200 120"><line x1="20" y1="40" x2="60" y2="40" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="20" y1="80" x2="60" y2="80" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 60 25 L 60 95 Q 120 95 120 60 Q 120 25 60 25" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><circle cx="128" cy="60" r="8" fill="white" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="136" y1="60" x2="180" y2="60" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><text x="20" y="35" font-size="12" fill="#374151">A</text><text x="20" y="95" font-size="12" fill="#374151">B</text><text x="165" y="55" font-size="12" fill="#374151">Q</text></svg>
questions.hint: Look at the D-shape (AND) with a bubble at the output. The bubble means 'NOT'.

questions.question: What is $1 \oplus 0$ (1 XOR 0)?
questions.hint: XOR returns $1$ when inputs are DIFFERENT. Are these inputs the same or different?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $25$?
questions.hint: Break $25$ into powers of $2$: $16 + 8 + 1$. Mark those positions with $1$s.

questions.question: What is $1 \barwedge 1$ (1 NAND 1)?
questions.hint: NAND means NOT-AND. First find $1 \land 1$, then invert (NOT) that result.

questions.question: What is this logic gate called?
questions.svg: <svg width="200" height="120" viewBox="0 0 200 120"><line x1="20" y1="40" x2="55" y2="40" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="20" y1="80" x2="55" y2="80" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 55 25 Q 65 25 65 60 Q 65 95 55 95 L 55 25" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 65 25 Q 120 45 120 60 Q 120 75 65 95" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><circle cx="128" cy="60" r="8" fill="white" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="136" y1="60" x2="180" y2="60" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><text x="20" y="35" font-size="12" fill="#374151">A</text><text x="20" y="95" font-size="12" fill="#374151">B</text><text x="165" y="55" font-size="12" fill="#374151">Q</text></svg>
questions.hint: The curved shield (OR) with a bubble at output. The bubble means 'NOT'.

questions.question: What is $0 \downarrow 0$ (0 NOR 0)?
questions.hint: NOR means NOT-OR. First find $0 \lor 0$, then invert that result.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $10110_2$?
questions.hint: Positions from right: $1, 2, 4, 8, 16$. Add positions where there's a $1$.

questions.question: What is $1 \downarrow 1$ (1 NOR 1)?
questions.hint: NOR means NOT-OR. First find $1 \lor 1$, then invert (NOT) that result.

questions.question: What is $0 \oplus 0$ (0 XOR 0)?
questions.hint: XOR returns $1$ when inputs are DIFFERENT. Are $0$ and $0$ different?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $31$?
questions.hint: $31 = 16 + 8 + 4 + 2 + 1$. How many positions is that?

questions.question: What is $0 \barwedge 1$ (0 NAND 1)?
questions.hint: NAND = NOT(AND). First find $0 \land 1$, then invert that result.

questions.question: What is the output? $A=1$, $B=1$ through an XOR gate.
questions.svg: <svg width="220" height="120" viewBox="0 0 220 120"><text x="10" y="45" font-size="12" fill="#374151">A=1</text><text x="10" y="85" font-size="12" fill="#374151">B=1</text><line x1="40" y1="40" x2="65" y2="40" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="40" y1="80" x2="65" y2="80" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 65 25 Q 75 25 75 60 Q 75 95 65 95 L 65 25" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 75 25 Q 130 45 130 60 Q 130 75 75 95" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="88" y1="50" x2="88" y2="70" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="130" y1="60" x2="180" y2="60" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><text x="185" y="65" font-size="18" fill="#EF4444">?</text></svg>
questions.hint: XOR gives $1$ when inputs DIFFER. When both inputs are the same...

questions.question: What is $1 + 1$ in binary?
questions.hint: In binary, $1 + 1$ carries over just like $9 + 1$ in decimal. What's $1 + 1$ with carry?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $11111_2$?
questions.hint: Add all positions: $16 + 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 = ?$

questions.question: What is $0 \downarrow 1$ (0 NOR 1)?
questions.hint: NOR = NOT(OR). First find $0 \lor 1$, then invert that result.

questions.question: What is the output? $A=0$, $B=1$ through a NAND gate.
questions.svg: <svg width="220" height="120" viewBox="0 0 220 120"><text x="10" y="45" font-size="12" fill="#374151">A=0</text><text x="10" y="85" font-size="12" fill="#374151">B=1</text><line x1="40" y1="40" x2="70" y2="40" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="40" y1="80" x2="70" y2="80" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><path d="M 70 25 L 70 95 Q 130 95 130 60 Q 130 25 70 25" fill="#E0E7FF" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><circle cx="138" cy="60" r="8" fill="white" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><line x1="146" y1="60" x2="180" y2="60" stroke="#4F46E5" stroke-width="2"/><text x="185" y="65" font-size="18" fill="#EF4444">?</text></svg>
questions.hint: NAND = NOT(AND). First calculate AND, then invert.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $20$?
questions.hint: $20 = 16 + 4$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $11_2 + 1$ in binary?
questions.hint: $11_2$ in binary is $3$ in decimal. Add $1$, then convert back to binary.

questions.question: What is $1 \barwedge 0$ (1 NAND 0)?
questions.hint: NAND = NOT(AND). What's $1 \land 0$? Then invert it.

questions.question: How many bits are in $1$ byte?
questions.hint: A byte is the standard unit for a character. It contains enough bits to represent $256$ values.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $100000_2$?
questions.hint: Count the position of the $1$ from the right (starting at $0$). It's $2$ raised to that power.

questions.question: What is $\overline{A \land B}$ (NOT(A AND B)) equivalent to?
questions.hint: What gate is literally defined as NOT followed by AND?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $50$?
questions.hint: $50 = 32 + 16 + 2$. Mark those positions with $1$s.

questions.question: What is $101_2 + 11_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $101_2 = 5$ and $11_2 = 3$ in decimal. Find their sum and convert back.

questions.question: What is $\overline{A \lor B}$ (NOT(A OR B)) equivalent to?
questions.hint: What gate is literally defined as NOT followed by OR?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $101010_2$?
questions.hint: Positions with $1$s are $32$, $8$, and $2$. Add them up.

questions.question: What is $0 \barwedge 0$ (0 NAND 0)?
questions.hint: NAND = NOT(AND). First find $0 \land 0$, then invert.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $63$?
questions.hint: $63 = 32 + 16 + 8 + 4 + 2 + 1$. That's all six positions!

questions.question: If $A=1$, $B=0$, what is $A \oplus B$?
questions.hint: XOR gives $1$ when inputs are DIFFERENT. Are $1$ and $0$ different?

questions.question: What is $1111_2 + 1$ in binary?
questions.hint: $1111_2 = 15$ in decimal. Add $1$ and convert the result to binary.

questions.question: What is the maximum value a byte can hold (unsigned)?
questions.hint: $8$ bits all set to $1$: what's the sum of $128+64+32+16+8+4+2+1$?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1000000_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$ is in the 7th position from right (starting at position $0$). What's $2^6$?

questions.question: What gate is also called an inverter?
questions.hint: Which gate takes one input and 'inverts' or flips it?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $100$?
questions.hint: $100 = 64 + 32 + 4$. Mark those positions with $1$s.

questions.question: What is $1010_2 - 11_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $1010_2 = 10$ and $11_2 = 3$ in decimal. Subtract and convert back.

questions.question: Which gate outputs $1$ when inputs are different?
questions.hint: This 'exclusive' gate returns $1$ only when exactly one input is $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1100100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $32$, and $4$. Add them up.

questions.question: A NAND gate with both inputs connected together acts as what gate?
questions.hint: When $A = B$, NAND gives $\overline{A \land A} = \overline{A}$. That's equivalent to which gate?

questions.question: What is $1 \downarrow 0$ (1 NOR 0)?
questions.hint: NOR = NOT(OR). First compute $1 \lor 0$, then invert the result.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $15$?
questions.hint: $15 = 8 + 4 + 2 + 1$. All four bits should be $1$.

questions.question: If both inputs to a NOR gate are $0$, what is the output?
questions.hint: NOR inverts the OR result. What is $0 \lor 0$, and what happens when you invert it?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1010_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $8$ and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $0 \oplus 1$ (0 XOR 1)?
questions.hint: XOR outputs $1$ when inputs differ. Are $0$ and $1$ the same or different?

questions.question: What is the output when $A=1$, $B=0$ through a NOR gate?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \lor 0$, then apply NOT to that result.

questions.question: What is $110_2 + 10_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $110_2 = 6$ and $10_2 = 2$. What is $6 + 2$ in binary?

questions.question: Which gate outputs $0$ only when both inputs are $1$?
questions.hint: This gate inverts the AND output. AND gives $1$ when both are $1$, so this gate gives...

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $7$?
questions.hint: $7 = 4 + 2 + 1$. Which three bits should be $1$?

questions.question: What is $(1 \land 1) \oplus 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \land 1$, then XOR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1111_2$?
questions.hint: Add all positions: $8 + 4 + 2 + 1 = ?$

questions.question: A NOR gate with both inputs connected together acts as what gate?
questions.hint: When $A = B$, NOR gives $\overline{A \lor A} = \overline{A}$. What single-input gate does this?

questions.question: What is the output when $A=0$, $B=0$ through a NAND gate?
questions.hint: NAND = NOT(AND). What is $0 \land 0$, and what happens when you invert it?

questions.question: What is $1001_2 - 1_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $1001_2 = 9$ in decimal. What is $9 - 1$ in binary?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $40$?
questions.hint: $40 = 32 + 8$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(0 \lor 1) \barwedge 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $0 \lor 1$, then NAND that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $10000_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$ is in position $4$ (counting from $0$). What is $2^4$?

questions.question: Which gate is known as a 'universal gate'?
questions.hint: This gate can be used to construct any other logic gate. Think about NOT-AND.

questions.question: What is $10_2 \times 11_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $10_2 = 2$ and $11_2 = 3$. What is $2 \times 3$ in binary?

questions.question: What is $(1 \oplus 0) \land 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \oplus 0$, then AND that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $8$?
questions.hint: $8$ is a power of $2$. How many zeros follow the $1$?

questions.question: What is the output when $A=1$, $B=1$ through a NOR gate?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \lor 1$, then invert the result.

questions.question: What is $\overline{0}$ (NOT 0)?
questions.hint: NOT flips the bit. What is the opposite of $0$?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $11000_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $16$ and $8$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(1 \barwedge 0) \downarrow 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1$ NAND $0$, then NOR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $12$?
questions.hint: $12 = 8 + 4$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: Which gate is also a 'universal gate' along with NAND?
questions.hint: Like NAND, this gate can construct all other logic gates. It's NOT-OR.

questions.question: What is $\overline{1}$ (NOT 1)?
questions.hint: NOT flips the bit. What is the opposite of $1$?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $10101_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $16$, $4$, and $1$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(0 \downarrow 0) \oplus 0$?
questions.hint: First compute $0$ NOR $0$, then XOR that result with $0$.

questions.question: What is $1100_2 + 100_2$ in binary?
What is the binary of decimal $5$?
questions.hint: $5 = 4 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \land 0) \lor 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \land 0$, then OR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $11100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $16$, $8$, and $4$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(1 \oplus 1) \barwedge 0$?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \oplus 1$, then NAND that result with $0$.

questions.question: How many different values can $4$ bits represent?
questions.hint: With $n$ bits, you can represent $2^n$ values. What is $2^4$?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $17$?
questions.hint: $17 = 16 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(0 \barwedge 0) \land 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $0$ NAND $0$, then AND that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $110_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $4$ and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $11_2 \times 11_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $11_2 = 3$. What is $3 \times 3$ in binary?

questions.question: What is the output of XOR when both inputs are $0$?
questions.hint: XOR outputs $1$ only when inputs differ. Are $0$ and $0$ different?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $30$?
questions.hint: $30 = 16 + 8 + 4 + 2$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \downarrow 0) \lor 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1$ NOR $0$, then OR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $111_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $4$, $2$, and $1$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $\overline{\overline{1}}$ (NOT NOT 1)?
questions.hint: Applying NOT twice returns the original value. What is $1$ after two inversions?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $64$?
questions.hint: $64 = 2^6$. How many zeros follow the leading $1$?

questions.question: What is $(0 \lor 0) \oplus 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $0 \lor 0$, then XOR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1001_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $8$ and $1$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $1000_2 - 1_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $1000_2 = 8$ in decimal. What is $8 - 1$ in binary?

questions.question: What is $(1 \land 1) \downarrow 0$?
questions.hint: First compute $1 \land 1$, then NOR that result with $0$.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $22$?
questions.hint: $22 = 16 + 4 + 2$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: Which operation does XOR perform in binary addition (ignoring carry)?
questions.hint: In a half adder, XOR gives the sum bit. What does $1 \oplus 1$ give for the sum?

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $10001_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $16$ and $1$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(0 \oplus 1) \land (1 \oplus 0)$?
questions.hint: Compute each XOR first, then AND the two results together.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $9$?
questions.hint: $9 = 8 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \barwedge 1) \oplus 1$?
questions.hint: First compute $1$ NAND $1$, then XOR that result with $1$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $11010_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $16$, $8$, and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $10_2 + 10_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $10_2 = 2$ in decimal. What is $2 + 2$ in binary?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $48$?
questions.hint: $48 = 32 + 16$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(0 \downarrow 1) \barwedge 0$?
questions.hint: First compute $0$ NOR $1$, then NAND that result with $0$.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $100100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $32$ and $4$. Add those values.

questions.question: Which operation does AND perform in binary addition?
questions.hint: In a half adder, AND generates the carry. When both inputs are $1$, we carry.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $35$?
questions.hint: $35 = 32 + 2 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \lor 0) \barwedge (0 \lor 1)$?
questions.hint: Compute each OR first, then NAND the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $101100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $32$, $8$, and $4$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $111_2 + 1_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $111_2 = 7$ in decimal. What is $7 + 1$ in binary?

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $55$?
questions.hint: $55 = 32 + 16 + 4 + 2 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \oplus 0) \downarrow (0 \oplus 1)$?
questions.hint: Compute each XOR first, then NOR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $111000_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $32$, $16$, and $8$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(0 \land 1) \oplus (1 \land 0)$?
questions.hint: Compute each AND first, then XOR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $60$?
questions.hint: $60 = 32 + 16 + 8 + 4$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $1010_2 + 101_2$ in binary?
What is the decimal value of binary $110110_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $32$, $16$, $4$, and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(1 \barwedge 0) \land (0 \barwedge 1)$?
questions.hint: Compute each NAND first, then AND the two results together.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $45$?
questions.hint: $45 = 32 + 8 + 4 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(0 \oplus 0) \lor (1 \oplus 1)$?
questions.hint: Compute each XOR first, then OR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1000010_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$ and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $100_2 \times 10_2$ in binary?
questions.hint: $100_2 = 4$ and $10_2 = 2$. What is $4 \times 2$ in binary?

questions.hint: $70 = 64 + 4 + 2$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.hint: Compute each NOR first, then XOR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1010100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $16$, and $4$. Add those values.

questions.hint: Compute each AND first, then NAND the two results together.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $75$?
questions.hint: $75 = 64 + 8 + 2 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $1100_2 - 101_2$ in binary?
What is the decimal value of binary $1011010_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $16$, $8$, and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(0 \lor 1) \downarrow (1 \lor 0)$?
questions.hint: Compute each OR first, then NOR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the binary of decimal $80$?
questions.hint: $80 = 64 + 16$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.question: What is $(1 \oplus 1) \downarrow (0 \oplus 0)$?
questions.hint: Compute each XOR first, then NOR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1100010_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $32$, and $2$. Add those values.

questions.hint: $11_2 = 3$ in decimal. What is $3 + 3$ in binary?

questions.hint: $90 = 64 + 16 + 8 + 2$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.hint: Compute each NAND first, then OR the two results together.

questions.question: What is the decimal value of binary $1101100_2$?
questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $32$, $8$, and $4$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $(0 \land 0) \oplus (1 \lor 1)$?
questions.hint: Compute the AND and OR first, then XOR the two results together.

questions.hint: $85 = 64 + 16 + 4 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.hint: Compute each NOR first, then AND the two results together.

questions.hint: $95 = 64 + 16 + 8 + 4 + 2 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $32$, $16$, and $8$. Add those values.

questions.hint: $101_2 = 5$ and $11_2 = 3$. What is $5 \times 3$ in binary?

questions.hint: $99 = 64 + 32 + 2 + 1$. Which positions need $1$s?

questions.hint: Compute each NAND first, then NOR the two results together.

questions.hint: The $1$s are at positions $64$, $32$, $16$, $8$, $4$, and $2$. Add those values.

questions.question: What is $((1 \oplus 0) \land 1) \barwedge 0$?
questions.hint: Work inside out: first XOR, then AND, finally NAND with $0$.
